description.narrative: 60% of South Africans seek out traditional health practitioners (THPs) and other community health workers (CHWs) when they fall ill. AMREF recognizes the importance of THPs to South Africans and thus developed this project. The goal of this project is to improve the health of rural poor and vulnerable populations - especially women and children in the targeted communities of Umkhanyakude District by improving the quality of health services provided by these CHWs, and increasing their recognition and integration into formal health systems. Umkhanyakude also has a high prevalence of HIV infections, and so CHWs are also trained in counseling skills, HIV prevention and care, linkages between STIs and HIV, and the importance of making referrals to hospitals and other health facilities.
Communities of Umkhanyakude, especially women and children

The project aims to achieve its objectives by:
1) Collaborating with the Ministry of Health on how to best integrate CHWs into the formal health system and create an information management system to test the capacity of CHWs and disseminate information
2) Increasing the capacity of CHWs to be better involved in basic health service delivery and integrating more women and children's health into training curriculums
3) Improving the quality of health information and promotion resources available in communities and increasing the skills of CHWs to be able to collect accurate and reliable community health data
4) Increasing participation and attendance of community members in health promotion activities including public engagement events with informative speakers
